🎯 حملة VisitDubai على TikTok... ماذا نتعلم؟في 2019 أطلقت hashtag#VisitDubai حملة رقمية ذكية استهدفت جيل الألفية (Millennials) عبر TikTok، بالتركيز على المحتوى القصير والموسيقى العصرية، تلتها حملات عديدة آخرها حملة hashtag#DubaiDestinations في صيف 2024.🎥 الحملات اعتمدت على:-        المؤثرين (Influencers)-        الفيديوهات السريعة الممتعة-        إبراز تجارب السفر اليومية بدل الترويج الكلاسيكي🔍 النتيجة؟ إنشاء آلاف مقاطع الفيديو من قبل المستخدمين لعرض تجاربهم في دبي، ملايين المشاهدات، وزيادة واضحة في نوايا السفر نحو دبي.هل يمكن أن نعيد هذه الفكرة للترويج للسياحة في الجزائر؟لماذا لا يكون لدينا "وجهات جزائرية" تظهر بنفس الأسلوب العصري؟المحتوى موجود، نحتاج فقط للجرأة الرقمية 🎯ما رأيكم؟ وهل لديكم أمثلة لحملات محلية مشابهة؟👇 hashtag#DigitalMarketing hashtag#TourismStrategy hashtag#TikTokMarketing hashtag#VisitAlgeria



…more

IPS Dubai was full of energy, innovation, and exciting real estate opportunities.As an architect who always steps into the client’s shoes, I couldn’t help but imagine how the visitor experience could have been more interactive, here is what came to mind :1. A clearer focus on what makes each project stand out would be inspiring.2. Interiors deserve as much spotlight as the beautiful façades.3. VR tech could elevate how people explore spaces.4. Pavilion layouts with more self-guided content could make discovery more intuitive—through interior models, videos, and visual storytelling.Personally, I thought Sustainable City 2.0 was a strong highlight, what I call an inspiring model for future developments. Yet, it felt a bit tech-heavy; a more interactive, human-centered experience could have made it the perfect blend for getting user engagement and interest.It was a great experience overall! and I’m excited to see how it evolves in the coming years!hashtag#IPSDubai hashtag#ArchitectureMatters hashtag#RealEstateInnovation hashtag#UserExperienceDesign hashtag#SustainableDesign hashtag#VRinRealEstate hashtag#InteriorDesignMatters hashtag#ArchitectPerspective hashtag#PropertyDevelopment

Post Content:
Renting vs Owning in Dubai – The Debate That Divides the SkylineLet’s break it once and for all:Renting a Property in DubaiPros: • No long-term commitment • Flexibility to move anytime • No maintenance headachesCons: • 100% money gone = 0 equity • Annual rent hikes • You’re paying someone else’s mortgageOwning a Property in DubaiPros: • Build equity over time • Stable payments (if mortgage) • Eligible for the Golden Visa (with AED 2M+ property) • Passive income through rental yieldsCons: • Initial down payment (usually 20–25%) • Long-term commitment • Market fluctuationsLet’s do the math:Paying AED 100,000/year in rent = AED 1 million burned in 10 years.Buy a property for AED 1.5M with 8% yield = AED 120,000/year income + value appreciation + Golden Visa.Now ask yourself:Do you want to rent your lifestyle or own your future?Because in Dubai, real estate isn’t just a transaction—it’s a transformation.Still confused? Let’s talk. I help people make life-changing moves every day.

The UAE Is Redefining Global Education InvestmentA massive move caught my attention: Mubadala and Dubai Holding joined forces with a global group to acquire Nord Anglia Education in a $14.5B deal one of the biggest education acquisitions ever.This isn’t just business. It’s a bold message: the hashtag#UAE isn’t just focusing on local education reform; it’s shaping how the world learns.Why does this matter? •	Mubadala’s $600M equity stake reflects a national strategy to invest in human capital and align with the UAE’s AI and innovation goals. •	Dubai Holding’s involvement shows how deeply education ties into the UAE’s positioning as a global hub for talent, families, and future industries. •	Nord Anglia isn’t just any operator 85,000+ students, 80+ schools in 33 countries, and partnerships with MIT, Juilliard, and UNICEF.The local context is just as powerful: •	827 international schools make the UAE #1 globally per capita. •	220+ of those are in Dubai alone. •	The UAE’s private K-12 market is projected to hit $7.1B by 2027. •	Education remains one of the largest priorities in the federal budget.This deal isn’t just about returns it’s about long term influence, future proofing our youth, and making the UAE a reference point for educational excellence worldwide.Smart nations build roads. Visionary ones build minds. 🇦🇪

Post Content:
شكر وتقدير كبير لأعضاء لجنة توجيه مسابقة جامعة دبي لريادة الأعمال على حضورهم الاجتماع الرسمي الأول اليوم. مساهماتكم القيمة وإرشاداتكم تساهم بشكل كبير في تحقيق نجاح هذه النسخة.• سعادة الدكتور عيسى م. البستكي، رئيس جامعة دبي.• سعادة السيد عبدالله القعود، مدير العمليات الرقمية في غرفة دبي.• سعادة السيد يوسف بن لاحج، نائب رئيس التوطين والشراكات الحكومية في طيران الإمارات.• سعادة السيد غانم الفلاسي، نائب الرئيس الأول للتكنولوجيا وريادة الأعمال في دبي Silicon Oasis.• سعادة الدكتور محمود البرعي، المدير الأول لسياسات الابتكار والعقارات في دائرة الأراضي والأملاك بدبي.• المهندس محمد عبود، مدير مركز الابتكار وريادة الأعمال في جامعة دبي.A heartfelt thank you and sincere appreciation to the esteemed members of the UD Pitch Competition Steering Committee for joining today’s first official meeting. Your insights and guidance are invaluable as we work together to make this edition more impactful, meaningful, and successful for all involved.• His Excellency Dr. Eesa Al Bastaki, President at University of Dubai.• His Excellency Mr. Abdulla Algaoud, Director of Digital Operations at Dubai Chambers.• His Excellency Mr. Yousef Bin Lahej, Vice President of Emiratisation and Government Partnership at Emirates. • His Excellency Mr. Ghanim Alfalasi, Senior VP of Technology & Entrepreneurship at Dubai Silicon Oasis.• His Excellency Dr Mahmoud AlBurai, Senior Director of Real Estate Policies and Innovation at the Dubai Land Department.• Eng. Mohamed Aboud, Manager of the Innovation and Entrepreneurship Business Center at University of Dubai.Together, we’ll turn vision into reality. Excited for what’s to come with this incredible committee!

As regional and global landscapes shift, expect Dubai’s role to grow even more prominent.hashtag#DubaiInvestment hashtag#ForeignInvestment hashtag#GlobalBusiness hashtag#UAE hashtag#RealEstate hashtag#EmergingMarkets hashtag#LinkedInBusiness hashtag#DubaiEconomy hashtag#BusinessHub

🎯 حملة VisitDubai على TikTok... ماذا نتعلم؟في 2019 أطلقت hashtag#VisitDubai حملة رقمية ذكية استهدفت جيل الألفية (Millennials) عبر TikTok، بالتركيز على المحتوى القصير والموسيقى العصرية، تلتها حملات عديدة آخرها حملة hashtag#DubaiDestinations في صيف 2024.🎥 الحملات اعتمدت على:-        المؤثرين (Influencers)-        الفيديوهات السريعة الممتعة-        إبراز تجارب السفر اليومية بدل الترويج الكلاسيكي🔍 النتيجة؟ إنشاء آلاف مقاطع الفيديو من قبل المستخدمين لعرض تجاربهم في دبي، ملايين المشاهدات، وزيادة واضحة في نوايا السفر نحو دبي.هل يمكن أن نعيد هذه الفكرة للترويج للسياحة في الجزائر؟لماذا لا يكون لدينا "وجهات جزائرية" تظهر بنفس الأسلوب العصري؟المحتوى موجود، نحتاج فقط للجرأة الرقمية 🎯ما رأيكم؟ وهل لديكم أمثلة لحملات محلية مشابهة؟👇 hashtag#DigitalMarketing hashtag#TourismStrategy hashtag#TikTokMarketing hashtag#VisitAlgeria

IPS Dubai was full of energy, innovation, and exciting real estate opportunities.As an architect who always steps into the client’s shoes, I couldn’t help but imagine how the visitor experience could have been more interactive, here is what came to mind :1. A clearer focus on what makes each project stand out would be inspiring.2. Interiors deserve as much spotlight as the beautiful façades.3. VR tech could elevate how people explore spaces.4. Pavilion layouts with more self-guided content could make discovery more intuitive—through interior models, videos, and visual storytelling.Personally, I thought Sustainable City 2.0 was a strong highlight, what I call an inspiring model for future developments. Yet, it felt a bit tech-heavy; a more interactive, human-centered experience could have made it the perfect blend for getting user engagement and interest.It was a great experience overall! and I’m excited to see how it evolves in the coming years!hashtag#IPSDubai hashtag#ArchitectureMatters hashtag#RealEstateInnovation hashtag#UserExperienceDesign hashtag#SustainableDesign hashtag#VRinRealEstate hashtag#InteriorDesignMatters hashtag#ArchitectPerspective hashtag#PropertyDevelopment

Post Content:
Renting vs Owning in Dubai – The Debate That Divides the SkylineLet’s break it once and for all:Renting a Property in DubaiPros: • No long-term commitment • Flexibility to move anytime • No maintenance headachesCons: • 100% money gone = 0 equity • Annual rent hikes • You’re paying someone else’s mortgageOwning a Property in DubaiPros: • Build equity over time • Stable payments (if mortgage) • Eligible for the Golden Visa (with AED 2M+ property) • Passive income through rental yieldsCons: • Initial down payment (usually 20–25%) • Long-term commitment • Market fluctuationsLet’s do the math:Paying AED 100,000/year in rent = AED 1 million burned in 10 years.Buy a property for AED 1.5M with 8% yield = AED 120,000/year income + value appreciation + Golden Visa.Now ask yourself:Do you want to rent your lifestyle or own your future?Because in Dubai, real estate isn’t just a transaction—it’s a transformation.Still confused? Let’s talk. I help people make life-changing moves every day.

The UAE Is Redefining Global Education InvestmentA massive move caught my attention: Mubadala and Dubai Holding joined forces with a global group to acquire Nord Anglia Education in a $14.5B deal one of the biggest education acquisitions ever.This isn’t just business. It’s a bold message: the hashtag#UAE isn’t just focusing on local education reform; it’s shaping how the world learns.Why does this matter? •	Mubadala’s $600M equity stake reflects a national strategy to invest in human capital and align with the UAE’s AI and innovation goals. •	Dubai Holding’s involvement shows how deeply education ties into the UAE’s positioning as a global hub for talent, families, and future industries. •	Nord Anglia isn’t just any operator 85,000+ students, 80+ schools in 33 countries, and partnerships with MIT, Juilliard, and UNICEF.The local context is just as powerful: •	827 international schools make the UAE #1 globally per capita. •	220+ of those are in Dubai alone. •	The UAE’s private K-12 market is projected to hit $7.1B by 2027. •	Education remains one of the largest priorities in the federal budget.This deal isn’t just about returns it’s about long term influence, future proofing our youth, and making the UAE a reference point for educational excellence worldwide.Smart nations build roads. Visionary ones build minds. 🇦🇪

Deloitte Middle East Announces Fastest Growing Technology Companies Rankings at Fourth Edition of Fast 50Deloitte Middle East has revealed the results of its fourth edition of its programme in the region, which highlights the fastest growing technology companies in the Middle East. - The program bases its rankings on the percentage of revenue growth during the past four years. Saudi Arabia topped the list in terms of the number of listed companies, accounting for 30%, followed by the United Arab Emirates with 28%, and Cyprus with 16%.- The average growth rate in the Fast 50 rankings reached 8,823%, with 29 companies recording growth of more than 1,000%, compared to only 21 companies in the previous version of the program. - Fintech (22%) and software (31%) maintained their position as the most prominent sectors on the list. - Saudi companies in the Fast 50 list: The delivery company "Mr. Mandoob" مستر مندوب | Mr Mandoob HR Technology Company KABi Artificial Intelligence Company "WAKEB" Wakeb_Data Accounting Solutions Qoyod - قيود Technical Solutions Company for Call Centers Maqsam Fintech company AreebArib Insurance Technology Company DESAISIV Interaction Technology Company Merit Incentives Experts Vision Consulting | EVC Company Environmental Technology Company Libelium Business Intelligence Solutions Linkers Technology Consumer Electronics Company Zension Technologies Inc. POS System Solutions Company "Lizzywait" LazyWait

IPS Dubai was full of energy, innovation, and exciting real estate opportunities.As an architect who always steps into the client’s shoes, I couldn’t help but imagine how the visitor experience could have been more interactive, here is what came to mind :1. A clearer focus on what makes each project stand out would be inspiring.2. Interiors deserve as much spotlight as the beautiful façades.3. VR tech could elevate how people explore spaces.4. Pavilion layouts with more self-guided content could make discovery more intuitive—through interior models, videos, and visual storytelling.Personally, I thought Sustainable City 2.0 was a strong highlight, what I call an inspiring model for future developments. Yet, it felt a bit tech-heavy; a more interactive, human-centered experience could have made it the perfect blend for getting user engagement and interest.It was a great experience overall! and I’m excited to see how it evolves in the coming years!hashtag#IPSDubai hashtag#ArchitectureMatters hashtag#RealEstateInnovation hashtag#UserExperienceDesign hashtag#SustainableDesign hashtag#VRinRealEstate hashtag#InteriorDesignMatters hashtag#ArchitectPerspective hashtag#PropertyDevelopment

Renting vs Owning in Dubai – The Debate That Divides the SkylineLet’s break it once and for all:Renting a Property in DubaiPros: • No long-term commitment • Flexibility to move anytime • No maintenance headachesCons: • 100% money gone = 0 equity • Annual rent hikes • You’re paying someone else’s mortgageOwning a Property in DubaiPros: • Build equity over time • Stable payments (if mortgage) • Eligible for the Golden Visa (with AED 2M+ property) • Passive income through rental yieldsCons: • Initial down payment (usually 20–25%) • Long-term commitment • Market fluctuationsLet’s do the math:Paying AED 100,000/year in rent = AED 1 million burned in 10 years.Buy a property for AED 1.5M with 8% yield = AED 120,000/year income + value appreciation + Golden Visa.Now ask yourself:Do you want to rent your lifestyle or own your future?Because in Dubai, real estate isn’t just a transaction—it’s a transformation.Still confused? Let’s talk. I help people make life-changing moves every day.

The UAE Is Redefining Global Education InvestmentA massive move caught my attention: Mubadala and Dubai Holding joined forces with a global group to acquire Nord Anglia Education in a $14.5B deal one of the biggest education acquisitions ever.This isn’t just business. It’s a bold message: the hashtag#UAE isn’t just focusing on local education reform; it’s shaping how the world learns.Why does this matter? •	Mubadala’s $600M equity stake reflects a national strategy to invest in human capital and align with the UAE’s AI and innovation goals. •	Dubai Holding’s involvement shows how deeply education ties into the UAE’s positioning as a global hub for talent, families, and future industries. •	Nord Anglia isn’t just any operator 85,000+ students, 80+ schools in 33 countries, and partnerships with MIT, Juilliard, and UNICEF.The local context is just as powerful: •	827 international schools make the UAE #1 globally per capita. •	220+ of those are in Dubai alone. •	The UAE’s private K-12 market is projected to hit $7.1B by 2027. •	Education remains one of the largest priorities in the federal budget.This deal isn’t just about returns it’s about long term influence, future proofing our youth, and making the UAE a reference point for educational excellence worldwide.Smart nations build roads. Visionary ones build minds. 🇦🇪

IPS Dubai was full of energy, innovation, and exciting real estate opportunities.As an architect who always steps into the client’s shoes, I couldn’t help but imagine how the visitor experience could have been more interactive, here is what came to mind :1. A clearer focus on what makes each project stand out would be inspiring.2. Interiors deserve as much spotlight as the beautiful façades.3. VR tech could elevate how people explore spaces.4. Pavilion layouts with more self-guided content could make discovery more intuitive—through interior models, videos, and visual storytelling.Personally, I thought Sustainable City 2.0 was a strong highlight, what I call an inspiring model for future developments. Yet, it felt a bit tech-heavy; a more interactive, human-centered experience could have made it the perfect blend for getting user engagement and interest.It was a great experience overall! and I’m excited to see how it evolves in the coming years!hashtag#IPSDubai hashtag#ArchitectureMatters hashtag#RealEstateInnovation hashtag#UserExperienceDesign hashtag#SustainableDesign hashtag#VRinRealEstate hashtag#InteriorDesignMatters hashtag#ArchitectPerspective hashtag#PropertyDevelopment

Renting vs Owning in Dubai – The Debate That Divides the SkylineLet’s break it once and for all:Renting a Property in DubaiPros: • No long-term commitment • Flexibility to move anytime • No maintenance headachesCons: • 100% money gone = 0 equity • Annual rent hikes • You’re paying someone else’s mortgageOwning a Property in DubaiPros: • Build equity over time • Stable payments (if mortgage) • Eligible for the Golden Visa (with AED 2M+ property) • Passive income through rental yieldsCons: • Initial down payment (usually 20–25%) • Long-term commitment • Market fluctuationsLet’s do the math:Paying AED 100,000/year in rent = AED 1 million burned in 10 years.Buy a property for AED 1.5M with 8% yield = AED 120,000/year income + value appreciation + Golden Visa.Now ask yourself:Do you want to rent your lifestyle or own your future?Because in Dubai, real estate isn’t just a transaction—it’s a transformation.Still confused? Let’s talk. I help people make life-changing moves every day.

The UAE Is Redefining Global Education InvestmentA massive move caught my attention: Mubadala and Dubai Holding joined forces with a global group to acquire Nord Anglia Education in a $14.5B deal one of the biggest education acquisitions ever.This isn’t just business. It’s a bold message: the hashtag#UAE isn’t just focusing on local education reform; it’s shaping how the world learns.Why does this matter? •	Mubadala’s $600M equity stake reflects a national strategy to invest in human capital and align with the UAE’s AI and innovation goals. •	Dubai Holding’s involvement shows how deeply education ties into the UAE’s positioning as a global hub for talent, families, and future industries. •	Nord Anglia isn’t just any operator 85,000+ students, 80+ schools in 33 countries, and partnerships with MIT, Juilliard, and UNICEF.The local context is just as powerful: •	827 international schools make the UAE #1 globally per capita. •	220+ of those are in Dubai alone. •	The UAE’s private K-12 market is projected to hit $7.1B by 2027. •	Education remains one of the largest priorities in the federal budget.This deal isn’t just about returns it’s about long term influence, future proofing our youth, and making the UAE a reference point for educational excellence worldwide.Smart nations build roads. Visionary ones build minds. 🇦🇪

Deloitte Middle East Announces Fastest Growing Technology Companies Rankings at Fourth Edition of Fast 50Deloitte Middle East has revealed the results of its fourth edition of its programme in the region, which highlights the fastest growing technology companies in the Middle East. - The program bases its rankings on the percentage of revenue growth during the past four years. Saudi Arabia topped the list in terms of the number of listed companies, accounting for 30%, followed by the United Arab Emirates with 28%, and Cyprus with 16%.- The average growth rate in the Fast 50 rankings reached 8,823%, with 29 companies recording growth of more than 1,000%, compared to only 21 companies in the previous version of the program. - Fintech (22%) and software (31%) maintained their position as the most prominent sectors on the list. - Saudi companies in the Fast 50 list: The delivery company "Mr. Mandoob" مستر مندوب | Mr Mandoob HR Technology Company KABi Artificial Intelligence Company "WAKEB" Wakeb_Data Accounting Solutions Qoyod - قيود Technical Solutions Company for Call Centers Maqsam Fintech company AreebArib Insurance Technology Company DESAISIV Interaction Technology Company Merit Incentives Experts Vision Consulting | EVC Company Environmental Technology Company Libelium Business Intelligence Solutions Linkers Technology Consumer Electronics Company Zension Technologies Inc. IPS Dubai was full of energy, innovation, and exciting real estate opportunities.As an architect who always steps into the client’s shoes, I couldn’t help but imagine how the visitor experience could have been more interactive, here is what came to mind :1. A clearer focus on what makes each project stand out would be inspiring.2. Interiors deserve as much spotlight as the beautiful façades.3. VR tech could elevate how people explore spaces.4. Pavilion layouts with more self-guided content could make discovery more intuitive—through interior models, videos, and visual storytelling.Personally, I thought Sustainable City 2.0 was a strong highlight, what I call an inspiring model for future developments. Yet, it felt a bit tech-heavy; a more interactive, human-centered experience could have made it the perfect blend for getting user engagement and interest.It was a great experience overall! and I’m excited to see how it evolves in the coming years!hashtag#IPSDubai hashtag#ArchitectureMatters hashtag#RealEstateInnovation hashtag#UserExperienceDesign hashtag#SustainableDesign hashtag#VRinRealEstate hashtag#InteriorDesignMatters hashtag#ArchitectPerspective hashtag#PropertyDevelopment

Renting vs Owning in Dubai – The Debate That Divides the SkylineLet’s break it once and for all:Renting a Property in DubaiPros: • No long-term commitment • Flexibility to move anytime • No maintenance headachesCons: • 100% money gone = 0 equity • Annual rent hikes • You’re paying someone else’s mortgageOwning a Property in DubaiPros: • Build equity over time • Stable payments (if mortgage) • Eligible for the Golden Visa (with AED 2M+ property) • Passive income through rental yieldsCons: • Initial down payment (usually 20–25%) • Long-term commitment • Market fluctuationsLet’s do the math:Paying AED 100,000/year in rent = AED 1 million burned in 10 years.Buy a property for AED 1.5M with 8% yield = AED 120,000/year income + value appreciation + Golden Visa.Now ask yourself:Do you want to rent your lifestyle or own your future?Because in Dubai, real estate isn’t just a transaction—it’s a transformation.Still confused? Let’s talk. I help people make life-changing moves every day.

The UAE Is Redefining Global Education InvestmentA massive move caught my attention: Mubadala and Dubai Holding joined forces with a global group to acquire Nord Anglia Education in a $14.5B deal one of the biggest education acquisitions ever.This isn’t just business. It’s a bold message: the hashtag#UAE isn’t just focusing on local education reform; it’s shaping how the world learns.Why does this matter? •	Mubadala’s $600M equity stake reflects a national strategy to invest in human capital and align with the UAE’s AI and innovation goals. •	Dubai Holding’s involvement shows how deeply education ties into the UAE’s positioning as a global hub for talent, families, and future industries. •	Nord Anglia isn’t just any operator 85,000+ students, 80+ schools in 33 countries, and partnerships with MIT, Juilliard, and UNICEF.The local context is just as powerful: •	827 international schools make the UAE #1 globally per capita. •	220+ of those are in Dubai alone. •	The UAE’s private K-12 market is projected to hit $7.1B by 2027. •	Education remains one of the largest priorities in the federal budget.This deal isn’t just about returns it’s about long term influence, future proofing our youth, and making the UAE a reference point for educational excellence worldwide.Smart nations build roads. Visionary ones build minds. 🇦🇪

شكر وتقدير كبير لأعضاء لجنة توجيه مسابقة جامعة دبي لريادة الأعمال على حضورهم الاجتماع الرسمي الأول اليوم. مساهماتكم القيمة وإرشاداتكم تساهم بشكل كبير في تحقيق نجاح هذه النسخة.• سعادة الدكتور عيسى م. البستكي، رئيس جامعة دبي.• سعادة السيد عبدالله القعود، مدير العمليات الرقمية في غرفة دبي.• سعادة السيد يوسف بن لاحج، نائب رئيس التوطين والشراكات الحكومية في طيران الإمارات.• سعادة السيد غانم الفلاسي، نائب الرئيس الأول للتكنولوجيا وريادة الأعمال في دبي Silicon Oasis.• سعادة الدكتور محمود البرعي، المدير الأول لسياسات الابتكار والعقارات في دائرة الأراضي والأملاك بدبي.• المهندس محمد عبود، مدير مركز الابتكار وريادة الأعمال في جامعة دبي.A heartfelt thank you and sincere appreciation to the esteemed members of the UD Pitch Competition Steering Committee for joining today’s first official meeting. Mohamed Aboud, Manager of the Innovation and Entrepreneurship Business Center at University of Dubai.Together, we’ll turn vision into reality. Excited for what’s to come with this incredible committee!

Deloitte Middle East Announces Fastest Growing Technology Companies Rankings at Fourth Edition of Fast 50Deloitte Middle East has revealed the results of its fourth edition of its programme in the region, which highlights the fastest growing technology companies in the Middle East. - The program bases its rankings on the percentage of revenue growth during the past four years. Saudi Arabia topped the list in terms of the number of listed companies, accounting for 30%, followed by the United Arab Emirates with 28%, and Cyprus with 16%.- The average growth rate in the Fast 50 rankings reached 8,823%, with 29 companies recording growth of more than 1,000%, compared to only 21 companies in the previous version of the program. - Fintech (22%) and software (31%) maintained their position as the most prominent sectors on the list. - Saudi companies in the Fast 50 list: The delivery company "Mr. Mandoob" مستر مندوب | Mr Mandoob HR Technology Company KABi Artificial Intelligence Company "WAKEB" Wakeb_Data Accounting Solutions Qoyod - قيود Technical Solutions Company for Call Centers Maqsam Fintech company AreebArib Insurance Technology Company DESAISIV Interaction Technology Company Merit Incentives Experts Vision Consulting | EVC Company Environmental Technology Company Libelium Business Intelligence Solutions Linkers Technology Consumer Electronics Company Zension Technologies Inc. IPS Dubai was full of energy, innovation, and exciting real estate opportunities.As an architect who always steps into the client’s shoes, I couldn’t help but imagine how the visitor experience could have been more interactive, here is what came to mind :1. A clearer focus on what makes each project stand out would be inspiring.2. Interiors deserve as much spotlight as the beautiful façades.3. VR tech could elevate how people explore spaces.4. Pavilion layouts with more self-guided content could make discovery more intuitive—through interior models, videos, and visual storytelling.Personally, I thought Sustainable City 2.0 was a strong highlight, what I call an inspiring model for future developments. Yet, it felt a bit tech-heavy; a more interactive, human-centered experience could have made it the perfect blend for getting user engagement and interest.It was a great experience overall! and I’m excited to see how it evolves in the coming years!hashtag#IPSDubai hashtag#ArchitectureMatters hashtag#RealEstateInnovation hashtag#UserExperienceDesign hashtag#SustainableDesign hashtag#VRinRealEstate hashtag#InteriorDesignMatters hashtag#ArchitectPerspective hashtag#PropertyDevelopment

Renting vs Owning in Dubai – The Debate That Divides the SkylineLet’s break it once and for all:Renting a Property in DubaiPros: • No long-term commitment • Flexibility to move anytime • No maintenance headachesCons: • 100% money gone = 0 equity • Annual rent hikes • You’re paying someone else’s mortgageOwning a Property in DubaiPros: • Build equity over time • Stable payments (if mortgage) • Eligible for the Golden Visa (with AED 2M+ property) • Passive income through rental yieldsCons: • Initial down payment (usually 20–25%) • Long-term commitment • Market fluctuationsLet’s do the math:Paying AED 100,000/year in rent = AED 1 million burned in 10 years.Buy a property for AED 1.5M with 8% yield = AED 120,000/year income + value appreciation + Golden Visa.Now ask yourself:Do you want to rent your lifestyle or own your future?Because in Dubai, real estate isn’t just a transaction—it’s a transformation.Still confused? Let’s talk. I help people make life-changing moves every day.

The UAE Is Redefining Global Education InvestmentA massive move caught my attention: Mubadala and Dubai Holding joined forces with a global group to acquire Nord Anglia Education in a $14.5B deal one of the biggest education acquisitions ever.This isn’t just business. It’s a bold message: the hashtag#UAE isn’t just focusing on local education reform; it’s shaping how the world learns.Why does this matter? •	Mubadala’s $600M equity stake reflects a national strategy to invest in human capital and align with the UAE’s AI and innovation goals. •	Dubai Holding’s involvement shows how deeply education ties into the UAE’s positioning as a global hub for talent, families, and future industries. •	Nord Anglia isn’t just any operator 85,000+ students, 80+ schools in 33 countries, and partnerships with MIT, Juilliard, and UNICEF.The local context is just as powerful: •	827 international schools make the UAE #1 globally per capita. •	220+ of those are in Dubai alone. •	The UAE’s private K-12 market is projected to hit $7.1B by 2027. •	Education remains one of the largest priorities in the federal budget.This deal isn’t just about returns it’s about long term influence, future proofing our youth, and making the UAE a reference point for educational excellence worldwide.Smart nations build roads. Visionary ones build minds. 🇦🇪

Deloitte Middle East Announces Fastest Growing Technology Companies Rankings at Fourth Edition of Fast 50Deloitte Middle East has revealed the results of its fourth edition of its programme in the region, which highlights the fastest growing technology companies in the Middle East. - The program bases its rankings on the percentage of revenue growth during the past four years. Saudi Arabia topped the list in terms of the number of listed companies, accounting for 30%, followed by the United Arab Emirates with 28%, and Cyprus with 16%.- The average growth rate in the Fast 50 rankings reached 8,823%, with 29 companies recording growth of more than 1,000%, compared to only 21 companies in the previous version of the program. - Fintech (22%) and software (31%) maintained their position as the most prominent sectors on the list. - Saudi companies in the Fast 50 list: The delivery company "Mr. Mandoob" مستر مندوب | Mr Mandoob HR Technology Company KABi Artificial Intelligence Company "WAKEB" Wakeb_Data Accounting Solutions Qoyod - قيود Technical Solutions Company for Call Centers Maqsam Fintech company AreebArib Insurance Technology Company DESAISIV Interaction Technology Company Merit Incentives Experts Vision Consulting | EVC Company Environmental Technology Company Libelium Business Intelligence Solutions Linkers Technology Consumer Electronics Company Zension Technologies Inc. IPS Dubai was full of energy, innovation, and exciting real estate opportunities.As an architect who always steps into the client’s shoes, I couldn’t help but imagine how the visitor experience could have been more interactive, here is what came to mind :1. A clearer focus on what makes each project stand out would be inspiring.2. Interiors deserve as much spotlight as the beautiful façades.3. VR tech could elevate how people explore spaces.4. Pavilion layouts with more self-guided content could make discovery more intuitive—through interior models, videos, and visual storytelling.Personally, I thought Sustainable City 2.0 was a strong highlight, what I call an inspiring model for future developments. Yet, it felt a bit tech-heavy; a more interactive, human-centered experience could have made it the perfect blend for getting user engagement and interest.It was a great experience overall! and I’m excited to see how it evolves in the coming years!hashtag#IPSDubai hashtag#ArchitectureMatters hashtag#RealEstateInnovation hashtag#UserExperienceDesign hashtag#SustainableDesign hashtag#VRinRealEstate hashtag#InteriorDesignMatters hashtag#ArchitectPerspective hashtag#PropertyDevelopment

Renting vs Owning in Dubai – The Debate That Divides the SkylineLet’s break it once and for all:Renting a Property in DubaiPros: • No long-term commitment • Flexibility to move anytime • No maintenance headachesCons: • 100% money gone = 0 equity • Annual rent hikes • You’re paying someone else’s mortgageOwning a Property in DubaiPros: • Build equity over time • Stable payments (if mortgage) • Eligible for the Golden Visa (with AED 2M+ property) • Passive income through rental yieldsCons: • Initial down payment (usually 20–25%) • Long-term commitment • Market fluctuationsLet’s do the math:Paying AED 100,000/year in rent = AED 1 million burned in 10 years.Buy a property for AED 1.5M with 8% yield = AED 120,000/year income + value appreciation + Golden Visa.Now ask yourself:Do you want to rent your lifestyle or own your future?Because in Dubai, real estate isn’t just a transaction—it’s a transformation.Still confused? Let’s talk. I help people make life-changing moves every day.

The UAE Is Redefining Global Education InvestmentA massive move caught my attention: Mubadala and Dubai Holding joined forces with a global group to acquire Nord Anglia Education in a $14.5B deal one of the biggest education acquisitions ever.This isn’t just business. It’s a bold message: the hashtag#UAE isn’t just focusing on local education reform; it’s shaping how the world learns.Why does this matter? •	Mubadala’s $600M equity stake reflects a national strategy to invest in human capital and align with the UAE’s AI and innovation goals. •	Dubai Holding’s involvement shows how deeply education ties into the UAE’s positioning as a global hub for talent, families, and future industries. •	Nord Anglia isn’t just any operator 85,000+ students, 80+ schools in 33 countries, and partnerships with MIT, Juilliard, and UNICEF.The local context is just as powerful: •	827 international schools make the UAE #1 globally per capita. •	220+ of those are in Dubai alone. •	The UAE’s private K-12 market is projected to hit $7.1B by 2027. •	Education remains one of the largest priorities in the federal budget.This deal isn’t just about returns it’s about long term influence, future proofing our youth, and making the UAE a reference point for educational excellence worldwide.Smart nations build roads. Visionary ones build minds. 🇦🇪

IPS Dubai was full of energy, innovation, and exciting real estate opportunities.As an architect who always steps into the client’s shoes, I couldn’t help but imagine how the visitor experience could have been more interactive, here is what came to mind :1. A clearer focus on what makes each project stand out would be inspiring.2. Interiors deserve as much spotlight as the beautiful façades.3. VR tech could elevate how people explore spaces.4. Pavilion layouts with more self-guided content could make discovery more intuitive—through interior models, videos, and visual storytelling.Personally, I thought Sustainable City 2.0 was a strong highlight, what I call an inspiring model for future developments. Yet, it felt a bit tech-heavy; a more interactive, human-centered experience could have made it the perfect blend for getting user engagement and interest.It was a great experience overall! and I’m excited to see how it evolves in the coming years!hashtag#IPSDubai hashtag#ArchitectureMatters hashtag#RealEstateInnovation hashtag#UserExperienceDesign hashtag#SustainableDesign hashtag#VRinRealEstate hashtag#InteriorDesignMatters hashtag#ArchitectPerspective hashtag#PropertyDevelopment

Renting vs Owning in Dubai – The Debate That Divides the SkylineLet’s break it once and for all:Renting a Property in DubaiPros: • No long-term commitment • Flexibility to move anytime • No maintenance headachesCons: • 100% money gone = 0 equity • Annual rent hikes • You’re paying someone else’s mortgageOwning a Property in DubaiPros: • Build equity over time • Stable payments (if mortgage) • Eligible for the Golden Visa (with AED 2M+ property) • Passive income through rental yieldsCons: • Initial down payment (usually 20–25%) • Long-term commitment • Market fluctuationsLet’s do the math:Paying AED 100,000/year in rent = AED 1 million burned in 10 years.Buy a property for AED 1.5M with 8% yield = AED 120,000/year income + value appreciation + Golden Visa.Now ask yourself:Do you want to rent your lifestyle or own your future?Because in Dubai, real estate isn’t just a transaction—it’s a transformation.Still confused? Let’s talk. I help people make life-changing moves every day.

The UAE Is Redefining Global Education InvestmentA massive move caught my attention: Mubadala and Dubai Holding joined forces with a global group to acquire Nord Anglia Education in a $14.5B deal one of the biggest education acquisitions ever.This isn’t just business. It’s a bold message: the hashtag#UAE isn’t just focusing on local education reform; it’s shaping how the world learns.Why does this matter? •	Mubadala’s $600M equity stake reflects a national strategy to invest in human capital and align with the UAE’s AI and innovation goals. •	Dubai Holding’s involvement shows how deeply education ties into the UAE’s positioning as a global hub for talent, families, and future industries. •	Nord Anglia isn’t just any operator 85,000+ students, 80+ schools in 33 countries, and partnerships with MIT, Juilliard, and UNICEF.The local context is just as powerful: •	827 international schools make the UAE #1 globally per capita. •	220+ of those are in Dubai alone. •	The UAE’s private K-12 market is projected to hit $7.1B by 2027. •	Education remains one of the largest priorities in the federal budget.This deal isn’t just about returns it’s about long term influence, future proofing our youth, and making the UAE a reference point for educational excellence worldwide.Smart nations build roads. Visionary ones build minds. 🇦🇪

Username: Jonathan Burns جونثان برنزJonathan Burns جونثان برنز
Post Content:
🌍 KSA’s New UBO Disclosure Rules – Initial Observations 🌍 The new Ultimate Beneficial Ownership (UBO) disclosure rules of the Ministry of Commerce have now been in effect in Saudi Arabia for two weeks. Based on early experience, here are some key features—and notable sticking points—of the framework:WHO IS SUBJECT TO THE OBLIGATION?👉 Only legal entities incorporated in KSA are required to comply. In practice, the entity will have a dedicated page within its government e-portal account to satisfy the UBO disclosure.👉 Important to note: Technically, the disclosure obligation does not extend to shareholders, foreign parent companies, or shell entities in the corporate chain. The responsibility lies with the KSA subsidiary.WHAT TRIGGERS A DISCLOSURE OBLIGATION?UBO disclosure obligations can be triggered objectively and subjectively: 1️⃣  Objectively, the obligation is triggered by having, directly or indirectly:  ▪️ ≥25% shareholding or voting rights in a KSA legal entity, and/or  ▪️ the power to appoint or dismiss a KSA legal entity’s manager, the majority of its board members, or its chairperson. 2️⃣ Subjectively, the obligation is triggered by having, directly or indirectly, the ability to “influence” a KSA legal entity’s operations or decisions.⚠️ Sticking point: “Influence” is not defined in the rules, leaving room for interpretation and potential compliance risk.WHO TRIGGERS THE OBLIGATION?👉 Natural persons meeting the above thresholds must be identified. HOWEVER, for corporate entities in the ownership chain meeting any of the above triggers, Article 4.1.e. requires the disclosure of a “legal representative”—even up through multiple levels.⚠️ Sticking point: “Legal representative” is also undefined and may vary depending on the jurisdiction of incorporation.WHEN MUST DISCLOSURE OCCUR?▪️ At incorporation for new entities▪️ By the next commercial register anniversary for existing entities⚠️ Sticking point: There is no grace period, meaning entities nearing their anniversary may face an urgent compliance timeline.📝 Looking ahead...Article 7.3 of the Rules provides that the Ministry will issue a detailed Guide, which should clarify these ambiguities. As of today, that guidance has not yet been released.This summary reflects general observations to date. There are exclusions, exceptions, and additional complexities not addressed here.hashtag#SaudiArabia hashtag#CorporateLaw hashtag#UBO hashtag#Compliance hashtag#RegulatoryUpdates hashtag#KSA hashtag#BusinessLaw hashtag#CorporateGovernance hashtag#MiddleEastLaw hashtag#LegalUpdates hashtag#MinistryOfCommerce hashtag#KSACompliance hashtag#BeneficialOwnership

Pavilion layouts with more self-guided content could make discovery more intuitive—through interior models, videos, and visual storytelling.Personally, I thought Sustainable City 2.0 was a strong highlight, what I call an inspiring model for future developments. Renting vs Owning in Dubai – The Debate That Divides the SkylineLet’s break it once and for all:Renting a Property in DubaiPros: • No long-term commitment • Flexibility to move anytime • No maintenance headachesCons: • 100% money gone = 0 equity • Annual rent hikes • You’re paying someone else’s mortgageOwning a Property in DubaiPros: • Build equity over time • Stable payments (if mortgage) • Eligible for the Golden Visa (with AED 2M+ property) • Passive income through rental yieldsCons: • Initial down payment (usually 20–25%) • Long-term commitment • Market fluctuationsLet’s do the math:Paying AED 100,000/year in rent = AED 1 million burned in 10 years.Buy a property for AED 1.5M with 8% yield = AED 120,000/year income + value appreciation + Golden Visa.Now ask yourself:Do you want to rent your lifestyle or own your future?Because in Dubai, real estate isn’t just a transaction—it’s a transformation.Still confused? Let’s talk. I help people make life-changing moves every day.

Username: Jonathan Burns جونثان برنزJonathan Burns جونثان برنز
Post Content:
🌍 KSA’s New UBO Disclosure Rules – Initial Observations 🌍 The new Ultimate Beneficial Ownership (UBO) disclosure rules of the Ministry of Commerce have now been in effect in Saudi Arabia for two weeks. Based on early experience, here are some key features—and notable sticking points—of the framework:WHO IS SUBJECT TO THE OBLIGATION?👉 Only legal entities incorporated in KSA are required to comply. In practice, the entity will have a dedicated page within its government e-portal account to satisfy the UBO disclosure.👉 Important to note: Technically, the disclosure obligation does not extend to shareholders, foreign parent companies, or shell entities in the corporate chain. The responsibility lies with the KSA subsidiary.WHAT TRIGGERS A DISCLOSURE OBLIGATION?UBO disclosure obligations can be triggered objectively and subjectively: 1️⃣  Objectively, the obligation is triggered by having, directly or indirectly:  ▪️ ≥25% shareholding or voting rights in a KSA legal entity, and/or  ▪️ the power to appoint or dismiss a KSA legal entity’s manager, the majority of its board members, or its chairperson. 2️⃣ Subjectively, the obligation is triggered by having, directly or indirectly, the ability to “influence” a KSA legal entity’s operations or decisions.⚠️ Sticking point: “Influence” is not defined in the rules, leaving room for interpretation and potential compliance risk.WHO TRIGGERS THE OBLIGATION?👉 Natural persons meeting the above thresholds must be identified. HOWEVER, for corporate entities in the ownership chain meeting any of the above triggers, Article 4.1.e. requires the disclosure of a “legal representative”—even up through multiple levels.⚠️ Sticking point: “Legal representative” is also undefined and may vary depending on the jurisdiction of incorporation.WHEN MUST DISCLOSURE OCCUR?▪️ At incorporation for new entities▪️ By the next commercial register anniversary for existing entities⚠️ Sticking point: There is no grace period, meaning entities nearing their anniversary may face an urgent compliance timeline.📝 Looking ahead...Article 7.3 of the Rules provides that the Ministry will issue a detailed Guide, which should clarify these ambiguities. As of today, that guidance has not yet been released.This summary reflects general observations to date. There are exclusions, exceptions, and additional complexities not addressed here.hashtag#SaudiArabia hashtag#CorporateLaw hashtag#UBO hashtag#Compliance hashtag#RegulatoryUpdates hashtag#KSA hashtag#BusinessLaw hashtag#CorporateGovernance hashtag#MiddleEastLaw hashtag#LegalUpdates hashtag#MinistryOfCommerce hashtag#KSACompliance hashtag#BeneficialOwnership

IPS Dubai was full of energy, innovation, and exciting real estate opportunities.As an architect who always steps into the client’s shoes, I couldn’t help but imagine how the visitor experience could have been more interactive, here is what came to mind :1. A clearer focus on what makes each project stand out would be inspiring.2. Interiors deserve as much spotlight as the beautiful façades.3. VR tech could elevate how people explore spaces.4. Pavilion layouts with more self-guided content could make discovery more intuitive—through interior models, videos, and visual storytelling.Personally, I thought Sustainable City 2.0 was a strong highlight, what I call an inspiring model for future developments. Username: Jonathan Burns جونثان برنزJonathan Burns جونثان برنز
Post Content:
🌍 KSA’s New UBO Disclosure Rules – Initial Observations 🌍 The new Ultimate Beneficial Ownership (UBO) disclosure rules of the Ministry of Commerce have now been in effect in Saudi Arabia for two weeks. Based on early experience, here are some key features—and notable sticking points—of the framework:WHO IS SUBJECT TO THE OBLIGATION?👉 Only legal entities incorporated in KSA are required to comply. In practice, the entity will have a dedicated page within its government e-portal account to satisfy the UBO disclosure.👉 Important to note: Technically, the disclosure obligation does not extend to shareholders, foreign parent companies, or shell entities in the corporate chain. The responsibility lies with the KSA subsidiary.WHAT TRIGGERS A DISCLOSURE OBLIGATION?UBO disclosure obligations can be triggered objectively and subjectively: 1️⃣  Objectively, the obligation is triggered by having, directly or indirectly:  ▪️ ≥25% shareholding or voting rights in a KSA legal entity, and/or  ▪️ the power to appoint or dismiss a KSA legal entity’s manager, the majority of its board members, or its chairperson. 2️⃣ Subjectively, the obligation is triggered by having, directly or indirectly, the ability to “influence” a KSA legal entity’s operations or decisions.⚠️ Sticking point: “Influence” is not defined in the rules, leaving room for interpretation and potential compliance risk.WHO TRIGGERS THE OBLIGATION?👉 Natural persons meeting the above thresholds must be identified. HOWEVER, for corporate entities in the ownership chain meeting any of the above triggers, Article 4.1.e. requires the disclosure of a “legal representative”—even up through multiple levels.⚠️ Sticking point: “Legal representative” is also undefined and may vary depending on the jurisdiction of incorporation.WHEN MUST DISCLOSURE OCCUR?▪️ At incorporation for new entities▪️ By the next commercial register anniversary for existing entities⚠️ Sticking point: There is no grace period, meaning entities nearing their anniversary may face an urgent compliance timeline.📝 Looking ahead...Article 7.3 of the Rules provides that the Ministry will issue a detailed Guide, which should clarify these ambiguities. As of today, that guidance has not yet been released.This summary reflects general observations to date. There are exclusions, exceptions, and additional complexities not addressed here.hashtag#SaudiArabia hashtag#CorporateLaw hashtag#UBO hashtag#Compliance hashtag#RegulatoryUpdates hashtag#KSA hashtag#BusinessLaw hashtag#CorporateGovernance hashtag#MiddleEastLaw hashtag#LegalUpdates hashtag#MinistryOfCommerce hashtag#KSACompliance hashtag#BeneficialOwnership



…more

Abu Dhabi will build the world’s first eSports island with a $280 million USD investment by True Gamers. UAE Doubles Down on Global Education: $14.5B Deal with Nord Anglia Education Signals New Era in Talent Investment In April 2025, Mubadala Investment Company and Dubai Holding joined a global consortium to acquire Nord Anglia Education a premium international schools operator in a $14.5 billion megadeal, one of the largest education-focused acquisitions in history.The UAE is no longer just educating its youth it’s investing in how the world learns.Who’s Involved in the $14.5B Consortium?1. EQT Group – Europe’s largest PE firm 2. Neuberger Berman 3. Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPP Investments)4. Corporación Financiera Alba5. Mubadala Investment Company – $600M stake (confirmed)6. Dubai Holding – strategic investor (amount undisclosed)Why Mubadala Made This InvestmentMubadala’s $600M equity stake is not just capital deployment it’s part of a national capability strategy:1. Human Capital First: Mubadala aligns with the UAE’s vision that education is the cornerstone of national prosperity.2. Future Workforce Fit: Nord Anglia’s AI, STEAM, and leadership programs are aligned with UAE’s AI Strategy 2031 and Fourth Industrial Revolution goals.3. Global Returns, Local Impact: Investing in a global operator helps bring best practices to the UAE and generate returns that diversify away from oil.Why Dubai Holding Joined the DealDubai Holding’s participation is deeply strategic it goes beyond finance and reflects a long-term vision:1. City Branding: Dubai aims to be the #1 global city for living, working, and raising families. World-class education is central to that.2. Direct Ecosystem Benefit: Nord Anglia already operates two leading schools in Dubai. This investment strengthens Dubai’s appeal to global talent and companies.3. Soft Power Diplomacy: Enhancing Dubai’s presence in global education circles elevates its cultural and institutional reputation.Why Nord Anglia?1. 85,000+ students | 80+ campuses | 33 countries2. Over 50% of students enter Top 100 QS-ranked universities3. Strategic partnerships with MIT, Juilliard, UNICEF4. AI, coding, entrepreneurship integrated from early stages5. Flagships in: Dubai, Abu Dhabi, New York, Dublin, Hong Kong, GenevaThe UAE’s Local Education Ecosystem:1. 827 international schools the largest per capita globally2. AED 26B ($7.1B): Projected UAE private K-12 market by 2027 3. 220+ international schools in Dubai alone4. 60,000+ new student seats added in 2 years5. 35% of UAE population is under 256. 89% expat population requires premium education options7. 40% of UAE’s federal budget (2025) allocated to social development education is the top priorityThis investment future-proofs the economy, drives educational reform, and expands the nation’s global influence in shaping knowledge ecosystems.This is how visionary nations invest not just in infrastructure but in intellect.

Renting vs Owning in Dubai – The Debate That Divides the SkylineLet’s break it once and for all:Renting a Property in DubaiPros: • No long-term commitment • Flexibility to move anytime • No maintenance headachesCons: • 100% money gone = 0 equity • Annual rent hikes • You’re paying someone else’s mortgageOwning a Property in DubaiPros: • Build equity over time • Stable payments (if mortgage) • Eligible for the Golden Visa (with AED 2M+ property) • Passive income through rental yieldsCons: • Initial down payment (usually 20–25%) • Long-term commitment • Market fluctuationsLet’s do the math:Paying AED 100,000/year in rent = AED 1 million burned in 10 years.Buy a property for AED 1.5M with 8% yield = AED 120,000/year income + value appreciation + Golden Visa.Now ask yourself:Do you want to rent your lifestyle or own your future?Because in Dubai, real estate isn’t just a transaction—it’s a transformation.Still confused? Let’s talk. I help people make life-changing moves every day.

Post Content:
🌍 KSA’s New UBO Disclosure Rules – Initial Observations 🌍 The new Ultimate Beneficial Ownership (UBO) disclosure rules of the Ministry of Commerce have now been in effect in Saudi Arabia for two weeks. Based on early experience, here are some key features—and notable sticking points—of the framework:WHO IS SUBJECT TO THE OBLIGATION?👉 Only legal entities incorporated in KSA are required to comply. In practice, the entity will have a dedicated page within its government e-portal account to satisfy the UBO disclosure.👉 Important to note: Technically, the disclosure obligation does not extend to shareholders, foreign parent companies, or shell entities in the corporate chain. The responsibility lies with the KSA subsidiary.WHAT TRIGGERS A DISCLOSURE OBLIGATION?UBO disclosure obligations can be triggered objectively and subjectively: 1️⃣  Objectively, the obligation is triggered by having, directly or indirectly:  ▪️ ≥25% shareholding or voting rights in a KSA legal entity, and/or  ▪️ the power to appoint or dismiss a KSA legal entity’s manager, the majority of its board members, or its chairperson. 2️⃣ Subjectively, the obligation is triggered by having, directly or indirectly, the ability to “influence” a KSA legal entity’s operations or decisions.⚠️ Sticking point: “Influence” is not defined in the rules, leaving room for interpretation and potential compliance risk.WHO TRIGGERS THE OBLIGATION?👉 Natural persons meeting the above thresholds must be identified. HOWEVER, for corporate entities in the ownership chain meeting any of the above triggers, Article 4.1.e. requires the disclosure of a “legal representative”—even up through multiple levels.⚠️ Sticking point: “Legal representative” is also undefined and may vary depending on the jurisdiction of incorporation.WHEN MUST DISCLOSURE OCCUR?▪️ At incorporation for new entities▪️ By the next commercial register anniversary for existing entities⚠️ Sticking point: There is no grace period, meaning entities nearing their anniversary may face an urgent compliance timeline.📝 Looking ahead...Article 7.3 of the Rules provides that the Ministry will issue a detailed Guide, which should clarify these ambiguities. As of today, that guidance has not yet been released.This summary reflects general observations to date. There are exclusions, exceptions, and additional complexities not addressed here.hashtag#SaudiArabia hashtag#CorporateLaw hashtag#UBO hashtag#Compliance hashtag#RegulatoryUpdates hashtag#KSA hashtag#BusinessLaw hashtag#CorporateGovernance hashtag#MiddleEastLaw hashtag#LegalUpdates hashtag#MinistryOfCommerce hashtag#KSACompliance hashtag#BeneficialOwnership

UAE Doubles Down on Global Education: $14.5B Deal with Nord Anglia Education Signals New Era in Talent Investment In April 2025, Mubadala Investment Company and Dubai Holding joined a global consortium to acquire Nord Anglia Education a premium international schools operator in a $14.5 billion megadeal, one of the largest education-focused acquisitions in history.The UAE is no longer just educating its youth it’s investing in how the world learns.Who’s Involved in the $14.5B Consortium?1. EQT Group – Europe’s largest PE firm 2. Neuberger Berman 3. Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPP Investments)4. Corporación Financiera Alba5. Mubadala Investment Company – $600M stake (confirmed)6. Dubai Holding – strategic investor (amount undisclosed)Why Mubadala Made This InvestmentMubadala’s $600M equity stake is not just capital deployment it’s part of a national capability strategy:1. Human Capital First: Mubadala aligns with the UAE’s vision that education is the cornerstone of national prosperity.2. Future Workforce Fit: Nord Anglia’s AI, STEAM, and leadership programs are aligned with UAE’s AI Strategy 2031 and Fourth Industrial Revolution goals.3. Global Returns, Local Impact: Investing in a global operator helps bring best practices to the UAE and generate returns that diversify away from oil.Why Dubai Holding Joined the DealDubai Holding’s participation is deeply strategic it goes beyond finance and reflects a long-term vision:1. City Branding: Dubai aims to be the #1 global city for living, working, and raising families. World-class education is central to that.2. Direct Ecosystem Benefit: Nord Anglia already operates two leading schools in Dubai. This investment strengthens Dubai’s appeal to global talent and companies.3. Soft Power Diplomacy: Enhancing Dubai’s presence in global education circles elevates its cultural and institutional reputation.Why Nord Anglia?1. 85,000+ students | 80+ campuses | 33 countries2. Over 50% of students enter Top 100 QS-ranked universities3. Strategic partnerships with MIT, Juilliard, UNICEF4. AI, coding, entrepreneurship integrated from early stages5. Flagships in: Dubai, Abu Dhabi, New York, Dublin, Hong Kong, GenevaThe UAE’s Local Education Ecosystem:1. 827 international schools the largest per capita globally2. AED 26B ($7.1B): Projected UAE private K-12 market by 2027 3. 220+ international schools in Dubai alone4. 60,000+ new student seats added in 2 years5. 35% of UAE population is under 256. 89% expat population requires premium education options7. 40% of UAE’s federal budget (2025) allocated to social development education is the top priorityThis investment future-proofs the economy, drives educational reform, and expands the nation’s global influence in shaping knowledge ecosystems.This is how visionary nations invest not just in infrastructure but in intellect.

IPS Dubai was full of energy, innovation, and exciting real estate opportunities.As an architect who always steps into the client’s shoes, I couldn’t help but imagine how the visitor experience could have been more interactive, here is what came to mind :1. A clearer focus on what makes each project stand out would be inspiring.2. Interiors deserve as much spotlight as the beautiful façades.3. VR tech could elevate how people explore spaces.4. Pavilion layouts with more self-guided content could make discovery more intuitive—through interior models, videos, and visual storytelling.Personally, I thought Sustainable City 2.0 was a strong highlight, what I call an inspiring model for future developments. Yet, it felt a bit tech-heavy; a more interactive, human-centered experience could have made it the perfect blend for getting user engagement and interest.It was a great experience overall! and I’m excited to see how it evolves in the coming years!hashtag#IPSDubai hashtag#ArchitectureMatters hashtag#RealEstateInnovation hashtag#UserExperienceDesign hashtag#SustainableDesign hashtag#VRinRealEstate hashtag#InteriorDesignMatters hashtag#ArchitectPerspective hashtag#PropertyDevelopment

Renting vs Owning in Dubai – The Debate That Divides the SkylineLet’s break it once and for all:Renting a Property in DubaiPros: • No long-term commitment • Flexibility to move anytime • No maintenance headachesCons: • 100% money gone = 0 equity • Annual rent hikes • You’re paying someone else’s mortgageOwning a Property in DubaiPros: • Build equity over time • Stable payments (if mortgage) • Eligible for the Golden Visa (with AED 2M+ property) • Passive income through rental yieldsCons: • Initial down payment (usually 20–25%) • Long-term commitment • Market fluctuationsLet’s do the math:Paying AED 100,000/year in rent = AED 1 million burned in 10 years.Buy a property for AED 1.5M with 8% yield = AED 120,000/year income + value appreciation + Golden Visa.Now ask yourself:Do you want to rent your lifestyle or own your future?Because in Dubai, real estate isn’t just a transaction—it’s a transformation.Still confused? Let’s talk. I help people make life-changing moves every day.

The UAE Is Redefining Global Education InvestmentA massive move caught my attention: Mubadala and Dubai Holding joined forces with a global group to acquire Nord Anglia Education in a $14.5B deal one of the biggest education acquisitions ever.This isn’t just business. It’s a bold message: the hashtag#UAE isn’t just focusing on local education reform; it’s shaping how the world learns.Why does this matter? •	Mubadala’s $600M equity stake reflects a national strategy to invest in human capital and align with the UAE’s AI and innovation goals. •	Dubai Holding’s involvement shows how deeply education ties into the UAE’s positioning as a global hub for talent, families, and future industries. •	Nord Anglia isn’t just any operator 85,000+ students, 80+ schools in 33 countries, and partnerships with MIT, Juilliard, and UNICEF.The local context is just as powerful: •	827 international schools make the UAE #1 globally per capita. •	220+ of those are in Dubai alone. •	The UAE’s private K-12 market is projected to hit $7.1B by 2027. •	Education remains one of the largest priorities in the federal budget.This deal isn’t just about returns it’s about long term influence, future proofing our youth, and making the UAE a reference point for educational excellence worldwide.Smart nations build roads. Visionary ones build minds. 🇦🇪

Username: Asset Homez International Properties LLCAsset Homez International Properties LLC
Post Content:
According to recent statistical data analysis, Dubai’s real estate sector recorded transactions exceeding AED 142 billion (US$38.7 billion) in the first quarter of the year. 🌍 KSA’s New UBO Disclosure Rules – Initial Observations 🌍 The new Ultimate Beneficial Ownership (UBO) disclosure rules of the Ministry of Commerce have now been in effect in Saudi Arabia for two weeks. Based on early experience, here are some key features—and notable sticking points—of the framework:WHO IS SUBJECT TO THE OBLIGATION?👉 Only legal entities incorporated in KSA are required to comply. In practice, the entity will have a dedicated page within its government e-portal account to satisfy the UBO disclosure.👉 Important to note: Technically, the disclosure obligation does not extend to shareholders, foreign parent companies, or shell entities in the corporate chain. The responsibility lies with the KSA subsidiary.WHAT TRIGGERS A DISCLOSURE OBLIGATION?UBO disclosure obligations can be triggered objectively and subjectively: 1️⃣  Objectively, the obligation is triggered by having, directly or indirectly:  ▪️ ≥25% shareholding or voting rights in a KSA legal entity, and/or  ▪️ the power to appoint or dismiss a KSA legal entity’s manager, the majority of its board members, or its chairperson. 2️⃣ Subjectively, the obligation is triggered by having, directly or indirectly, the ability to “influence” a KSA legal entity’s operations or decisions.⚠️ Sticking point: “Influence” is not defined in the rules, leaving room for interpretation and potential compliance risk.WHO TRIGGERS THE OBLIGATION?👉 Natural persons meeting the above thresholds must be identified. HOWEVER, for corporate entities in the ownership chain meeting any of the above triggers, Article 4.1.e. requires the disclosure of a “legal representative”—even up through multiple levels.⚠️ Sticking point: “Legal representative” is also undefined and may vary depending on the jurisdiction of incorporation.WHEN MUST DISCLOSURE OCCUR?▪️ At incorporation for new entities▪️ By the next commercial register anniversary for existing entities⚠️ Sticking point: There is no grace period, meaning entities nearing their anniversary may face an urgent compliance timeline.📝 Looking ahead...Article 7.3 of the Rules provides that the Ministry will issue a detailed Guide, which should clarify these ambiguities. As of today, that guidance has not yet been released.This summary reflects general observations to date. There are exclusions, exceptions, and additional complexities not addressed here.hashtag#SaudiArabia hashtag#CorporateLaw hashtag#UBO hashtag#Compliance hashtag#RegulatoryUpdates hashtag#KSA hashtag#BusinessLaw hashtag#CorporateGovernance hashtag#MiddleEastLaw hashtag#LegalUpdates hashtag#MinistryOfCommerce hashtag#KSACompliance hashtag#BeneficialOwnership

EQT Group – Europe’s largest PE firm 2. Neuberger Berman 3. Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPP Investments)4. Corporación Financiera Alba5. Mubadala Investment Company – $600M stake (confirmed)6. Dubai Holding – strategic investor (amount undisclosed)Why Mubadala Made This InvestmentMubadala’s $600M equity stake is not just capital deployment it’s part of a national capability strategy:1. Human Capital First: Mubadala aligns with the UAE’s vision that education is the cornerstone of national prosperity.2. Future Workforce Fit: Nord Anglia’s AI, STEAM, and leadership programs are aligned with UAE’s AI Strategy 2031 and Fourth Industrial Revolution goals.3. Global Returns, Local Impact: Investing in a global operator helps bring best practices to the UAE and generate returns that diversify away from oil.Why Dubai Holding Joined the DealDubai Holding’s participation is deeply strategic it goes beyond finance and reflects a long-term vision:1. City Branding: Dubai aims to be the #1 global city for living, working, and raising families. World-class education is central to that.2. Direct Ecosystem Benefit: Nord Anglia already operates two leading schools in Dubai. This investment strengthens Dubai’s appeal to global talent and companies.3. Soft Power Diplomacy: Enhancing Dubai’s presence in global education circles elevates its cultural and institutional reputation.Why Nord Anglia?1. 85,000+ students | 80+ campuses | 33 countries2. Over 50% of students enter Top 100 QS-ranked universities3. Strategic partnerships with MIT, Juilliard, UNICEF4. AI, coding, entrepreneurship integrated from early stages5. Flagships in: Dubai, Abu Dhabi, New York, Dublin, Hong Kong, GenevaThe UAE’s Local Education Ecosystem:1. 827 international schools the largest per capita globally2. AED 26B ($7.1B): Projected UAE private K-12 market by 2027 3. 220+ international schools in Dubai alone4. 60,000+ new student seats added in 2 years5. 35% of UAE population is under 256. 89% expat population requires premium education options7. 40% of UAE’s federal budget (2025) allocated to social development education is the top priorityThis investment future-proofs the economy, drives educational reform, and expands the nation’s global influence in shaping knowledge ecosystems.This is how visionary nations invest not just in infrastructure but in intellect.

A Dubai-based developer called me in a panic.They were finalizing a luxury residential sale — but their VAT refund worth AED 58,000 had been stuck for months.Here’s what happened: → They missed the filing deadline for Q3 → Filed Q4 late, without reconciling Q3 → FTA flagged both and paused refund processing → Meanwhile, cash flow was blocked — delaying their payment to a contractorTotal cost: → AED 4,000 in late fines → AED 58,000 refund delayed → AED 400K project payment stuck for 3 weeks📌 Late filings aren’t just a fine — they block cash, refunds, and deals.What we did: → Filed voluntary disclosures for both quarters → Reconciled past returns and cleared documentation gaps → Recovered the refund in 29 days💬 DM me “VAT Fix” if you’ve missed deadlines in the past 6 months — let’s prevent penalties before they pile up.hashtag#UAERealEstate hashtag#VATCompliance hashtag#FTA hashtag#CashFlow

Username: Jonathan Burns جونثان برنزJonathan Burns جونثان برنز
Post Content:
🌍 KSA’s New UBO Disclosure Rules – Initial Observations 🌍 The new Ultimate Beneficial Ownership (UBO) disclosure rules of the Ministry of Commerce have now been in effect in Saudi Arabia for two weeks. Based on early experience, here are some key features—and notable sticking points—of the framework:WHO IS SUBJECT TO THE OBLIGATION?👉 Only legal entities incorporated in KSA are required to comply. In practice, the entity will have a dedicated page within its government e-portal account to satisfy the UBO disclosure.👉 Important to note: Technically, the disclosure obligation does not extend to shareholders, foreign parent companies, or shell entities in the corporate chain. The responsibility lies with the KSA subsidiary.WHAT TRIGGERS A DISCLOSURE OBLIGATION?UBO disclosure obligations can be triggered objectively and subjectively: 1️⃣  Objectively, the obligation is triggered by having, directly or indirectly:  ▪️ ≥25% shareholding or voting rights in a KSA legal entity, and/or  ▪️ the power to appoint or dismiss a KSA legal entity’s manager, the majority of its board members, or its chairperson. 2️⃣ Subjectively, the obligation is triggered by having, directly or indirectly, the ability to “influence” a KSA legal entity’s operations or decisions.⚠️ Sticking point: “Influence” is not defined in the rules, leaving room for interpretation and potential compliance risk.WHO TRIGGERS THE OBLIGATION?👉 Natural persons meeting the above thresholds must be identified. HOWEVER, for corporate entities in the ownership chain meeting any of the above triggers, Article 4.1.e. requires the disclosure of a “legal representative”—even up through multiple levels.⚠️ Sticking point: “Legal representative” is also undefined and may vary depending on the jurisdiction of incorporation.WHEN MUST DISCLOSURE OCCUR?▪️ At incorporation for new entities▪️ By the next commercial register anniversary for existing entities⚠️ Sticking point: There is no grace period, meaning entities nearing their anniversary may face an urgent compliance timeline.📝 Looking ahead...Article 7.3 of the Rules provides that the Ministry will issue a detailed Guide, which should clarify these ambiguities. As of today, that guidance has not yet been released.This summary reflects general observations to date. There are exclusions, exceptions, and additional complexities not addressed here.hashtag#SaudiArabia hashtag#CorporateLaw hashtag#UBO hashtag#Compliance hashtag#RegulatoryUpdates hashtag#KSA hashtag#BusinessLaw hashtag#CorporateGovernance hashtag#MiddleEastLaw hashtag#LegalUpdates hashtag#MinistryOfCommerce hashtag#KSACompliance hashtag#BeneficialOwnership

UAE Doubles Down on Global Education: $14.5B Deal with Nord Anglia Education Signals New Era in Talent Investment In April 2025, Mubadala Investment Company and Dubai Holding joined a global consortium to acquire Nord Anglia Education a premium international schools operator in a $14.5 billion megadeal, one of the largest education-focused acquisitions in history.The UAE is no longer just educating its youth it’s investing in how the world learns.Who’s Involved in the $14.5B Consortium?1. EQT Group – Europe’s largest PE firm 2. Neuberger Berman 3. Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPP Investments)4. Corporación Financiera Alba5. Mubadala Investment Company – $600M stake (confirmed)6. Dubai Holding – strategic investor (amount undisclosed)Why Mubadala Made This InvestmentMubadala’s $600M equity stake is not just capital deployment it’s part of a national capability strategy:1. Human Capital First: Mubadala aligns with the UAE’s vision that education is the cornerstone of national prosperity.2. Future Workforce Fit: Nord Anglia’s AI, STEAM, and leadership programs are aligned with UAE’s AI Strategy 2031 and Fourth Industrial Revolution goals.3. Global Returns, Local Impact: Investing in a global operator helps bring best practices to the UAE and generate returns that diversify away from oil.Why Dubai Holding Joined the DealDubai Holding’s participation is deeply strategic it goes beyond finance and reflects a long-term vision:1. City Branding: Dubai aims to be the #1 global city for living, working, and raising families. World-class education is central to that.2. Direct Ecosystem Benefit: Nord Anglia already operates two leading schools in Dubai. This investment strengthens Dubai’s appeal to global talent and companies.3. Soft Power Diplomacy: Enhancing Dubai’s presence in global education circles elevates its cultural and institutional reputation.Why Nord Anglia?1. 85,000+ students | 80+ campuses | 33 countries2. Over 50% of students enter Top 100 QS-ranked universities3. Strategic partnerships with MIT, Juilliard, UNICEF4. AI, coding, entrepreneurship integrated from early stages5. Flagships in: Dubai, Abu Dhabi, New York, Dublin, Hong Kong, GenevaThe UAE’s Local Education Ecosystem:1. 827 international schools the largest per capita globally2. AED 26B ($7.1B): Projected UAE private K-12 market by 2027 3. 220+ international schools in Dubai alone4. 60,000+ new student seats added in 2 years5. 35% of UAE population is under 256. 89% expat population requires premium education options7. 40% of UAE’s federal budget (2025) allocated to social development education is the top priorityThis investment future-proofs the economy, drives educational reform, and expands the nation’s global influence in shaping knowledge ecosystems.This is how visionary nations invest not just in infrastructure but in intellect.

A Dubai-based developer called me in a panic.They were finalizing a luxury residential sale — but their VAT refund worth AED 58,000 had been stuck for months.Here’s what happened: → They missed the filing deadline for Q3 → Filed Q4 late, without reconciling Q3 → FTA flagged both and paused refund processing → Meanwhile, cash flow was blocked — delaying their payment to a contractorTotal cost: → AED 4,000 in late fines → AED 58,000 refund delayed → AED 400K project payment stuck for 3 weeks📌 Late filings aren’t just a fine — they block cash, refunds, and deals.What we did: → Filed voluntary disclosures for both quarters → Reconciled past returns and cleared documentation gaps → Recovered the refund in 29 days💬 DM me “VAT Fix” if you’ve missed deadlines in the past 6 months — let’s prevent penalties before they pile up.hashtag#UAERealEstate hashtag#VATCompliance hashtag#FTA hashtag#CashFlow

🩺  Unlocking Healthcare Excellence in the Middle East: Top Destinations, Leading Doctors, and the Road Ahead (part 1)As the Middle East continues its rapid transformation, one sector rising to the forefront is healthcare. Over the last decade, we’ve witnessed an incredible evolution- not just in infrastructure but in innovation, specialization, and global reputation. Countries across the region are now competing not only to serve their local populations but also to become global hubs for medical tourism.Here’s a look at where things stand, who’s leading the charge, and what opportunities lie ahead.🏥 Top Healthcare Destinations in the Middle East1. IranOften underrepresented in international rankings due to geopolitical factors, Iran is in fact one of the most advanced medical ecosystems in the region. With a high density of top-tier specialists, state-of-the-art surgical centers, and remarkably affordable pricing, Iran has become a go-to destination for patients from neighboring countries, Central Asia, and even Europe. From oncology and transplant surgery to fertility and reconstructive procedures, Iranian doctors are not only highly skilled but also often pioneers in their fields. Cities like Tehran, Shiraz, Mashhad, and Isfahan host globally respected hospitals and research institutions.2. United Arab Emirates (UAE)Dubai and Abu Dhabi have positioned themselves as world-class medical tourism destinations. With internationally accredited hospitals like Cleveland Clinic Abu Dhabi and Dubai Healthcare City, the UAE is attracting patients from across the GCC, Africa, and beyond.3. Saudi Arabia As part of Vision 2030, Saudi Arabia is heavily investing in transforming its healthcare sector. Riyadh and Jeddah now host a growing number of specialized hospitals, and the Kingdom is actively pursuing public-private partnerships (PPPs) to fast-track innovation and infrastructure.4. QatarHome to Sidra Medicine and Hamad Medical Corporation, Qatar is building a reputation for excellence in pediatric and women's health, with a strong focus on research and academic partnerships.5. Jordan and LebanonKnown for decades as go-to destinations for affordable, high-quality care, particularly in cardiology, oncology, and cosmetic procedures. These countries remain key players, especially for patients from North Africa and the Levant.hashtag#Healthcare hashtag#MiddleEast hashtag#HealthTech hashtag#Investment hashtag#Innovation hashtag#DigitalHealth hashtag#Iran hashtag#UAE hashtag#Saudiarabia hashtag#Qatar hashtag#Jordan hashtag#Lebanon hashtag#doctor

IPS Dubai was full of energy, innovation, and exciting real estate opportunities.As an architect who always steps into the client’s shoes, I couldn’t help but imagine how the visitor experience could have been more interactive, here is what came to mind :1. A clearer focus on what makes each project stand out would be inspiring.2. Interiors deserve as much spotlight as the beautiful façades.3. VR tech could elevate how people explore spaces.4. Pavilion layouts with more self-guided content could make discovery more intuitive—through interior models, videos, and visual storytelling.Personally, I thought Sustainable City 2.0 was a strong highlight, what I call an inspiring model for future developments. Yet, it felt a bit tech-heavy; a more interactive, human-centered experience could have made it the perfect blend for getting user engagement and interest.It was a great experience overall! and I’m excited to see how it evolves in the coming years!hashtag#IPSDubai hashtag#ArchitectureMatters hashtag#RealEstateInnovation hashtag#UserExperienceDesign hashtag#SustainableDesign hashtag#VRinRealEstate hashtag#InteriorDesignMatters hashtag#ArchitectPerspective hashtag#PropertyDevelopment

Renting vs Owning in Dubai – The Debate That Divides the SkylineLet’s break it once and for all:Renting a Property in DubaiPros: • No long-term commitment • Flexibility to move anytime • No maintenance headachesCons: • 100% money gone = 0 equity • Annual rent hikes • You’re paying someone else’s mortgageOwning a Property in DubaiPros: • Build equity over time • Stable payments (if mortgage) • Eligible for the Golden Visa (with AED 2M+ property) • Passive income through rental yieldsCons: • Initial down payment (usually 20–25%) • Long-term commitment • Market fluctuationsLet’s do the math:Paying AED 100,000/year in rent = AED 1 million burned in 10 years.Buy a property for AED 1.5M with 8% yield = AED 120,000/year income + value appreciation + Golden Visa.Now ask yourself:Do you want to rent your lifestyle or own your future?Because in Dubai, real estate isn’t just a transaction—it’s a transformation.Still confused? Let’s talk. I help people make life-changing moves every day.
